text: This is Starflow, Apple's newest entry into the AI image and video editing space going up against Open AI Midjourney and even Nano Banana Pro by using a unique auto reggressive flow architecture that creates great images and videos with much lower computational demands. And the best part is it's free and open- source. But why are Apple doing this? Do they really want users to generate images on their iPhones? Let's find out. And before we do, don't forget to hit subscribe. Fun fact, Apple have 375 repos on GitHub and 200 of them are related to machine learning, which is weird [music] to think that Apple is slowly turning into an AI company. But in this video, we're only going to focus on one of those repositories. Scalable auto reggressive flow or starflow for short contains two models, one for image and one for video generation announced way back in June, but they uploaded the code for it last month with some instructions on how to set it up and showed some examples on their site. We'll go through both of those later, but first, what makes Starflow so special? Well, Starflow uses a hybrid auto reggressive normalizing flow architecture. Yeah, let's break that down. An auto reggressive model is one that automatically predicts the next step based on the previous ones. So, chat GPT will come up with the next word based on what it said before. And an auto reggressive image model will [music] create a picture pixel by pixel based on the previous pixels which is different from the typical diffusion model used for [music] image generation that starts off with Gaussian noise that gradually gets dnoised to form a coherent image. But what's weird about starlow is that it's an auto reggressive model that does use gorsian noise. How? Well, this is where the normalizing flow part comes in. A normalizing flow model transforms a simple probability distribution like Gaussian into a more complex one using inversible functions also known as flow layers. So similar to diffusion starflow transforms a clean Gaussian into a coherent image but instead of denoising it uses multiple flow layers that can do the whole process in a single forward pass. Unlike diffusion which could use tens or thousands of passes. And the auto reggressive part actually applies to the flow layers which are computationally expensive since the layers transform patches of an image and the auto reggressive cost grows quadratically with the number of patches in every layer. But Starflow gets around this using parallel Jacobe iterations to solve the same auto reggressive equations simultaneously making the process up to 15 times faster especially for video generation. And because normalizing flows are invertible, it's possible to go from final image all the way back to the noise stage and even go from noise back to the exact same final image. [music] which means it's possible to tweak a small part of an image or

But the milliondoll question is, do these models work on a local device like an iPhone? Not exactly. Right now, Starflow requires a Python environment, PyTorch, and GPU resources for inference. It's not even optimized for Apple silicon or metal. So, while image generation could work on an M5 MacBook Pro, video generation, however, would be a nightmare. Besides, Starflow is currently a research project that only has one checkpoint publicly available, even though their documentation shows higher resolution images and even videos.
